source.raw_text:
The Straight-Arm Plank (or High Plank) is a full-body isometric exercise primarily targeting your core (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis, obliques), shoulders (deltoids, serratus anterior), and arms (triceps, biceps), while also engaging your chest, back (lats, rhomboids, traps), glutes, quads, and hamstrings for stabilization, building core stability, posture, and overall functional strength. It's an isometric hold, meaning muscles contract without changing length, focusing on static strength and endurance. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core: Transverse Abdominis, Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Erector Spinae, Multifidi, Pelvic Floor. 
• Shoulders & Arms: Deltoids, Triceps, Biceps, Pectoralis Major, Serratus Anterior, Trapezius. 
• Back: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids. 
• Lower Body: Glutes, Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Calves, Hip Flexors. [1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Pattern 

• Isometric Hold: You maintain a static, straight line from head to heels, pushing up through your hands like the top of a push-up. 
• Stabilization: Your body constantly works to resist gravity and prevent sagging or arching, requiring simultaneous contraction from numerous stabilizing muscles. 
• Anti-Rotation: Especially in variations like plank shoulder taps, the movement pattern challenges your body to resist rotation, strengthening the obliques and serratus anterior for better balance and functional movement. [2, 6, 10, 11, 12]  

Key Benefits 

• Improves posture and spinal stability. 
• Builds functional strength for daily activities. 
• Enhances overall body control and injury prevention, especially for the lower back. [2, 5, 10, 12]
